summary:
Wade: aight Petey I'm gonna teach you to roll the fattest blunt the world has ever seen.
Peter: Wade, no, please. Tony literally...
body:
Wade: aight Petey I’m gonna teach you to roll the fattest blunt the world has ever seen.

Peter: Wade, no, please. Tony literally just let you back into the tower-

Wade: *sits him down* this is important.

Peter: ;-; alright,,,

-surprise, Wade was kicked out again-

summary: Miles Morales: The Hardest Hero To Be
body:
Miles Morales: The Hardest Hero To Be

Miles Morales is Spider-Man. Spider-Man has an extrasensory perception called Spider Sense that alerts him to danger. I’m not aware that Spider Sense is limited to alerts based on the kind of danger perceived. So it’s entirely possible the power kicks in for psychological dangers as well as more ordinary physical dangers (well, ordinary as far as physical dangers go for a superhero).

Miles Morales is Afro-Latino, and someone who would probably be received as black if he doesn’t have an accent (heck, it’s America, he’d probably be seen as black regardless of an accent). There are a number of dangers a black person—or someone seen as black—in the U.S. navigates daily. Some are physical dangers, but an equal or greater number are psychological in nature (i.e., the many expressions of racism).

Miles Morales’ Spider Sense must constanty warn him off danger. Confusingly, he is probably constanty alerted to dangers he can’t see, small expressions of racial hostility that he may not be able to recognize or process as they are occurring (he is a kid after all). All the same, his power recognizes the threats unique to a black person and responds like it does to all other dangerous situations he encounters, situations that are more in line with his work as a superhero.

Miles Morales must be constantly on-edge and stressed out by the near-constant alerts to danger. The stress might prevent him from resting while awake or asleep, and from eating. Over time, the power may rob him of the ability to derive joy from both ordinary and special activities. His health, in both the short and long terms, probably suffers as a result. But still he dons the mask to protect his community. That’s a hard life, especially for one so young.


**Edits for spelling grammar.**

summary: Amazing Spider-Man Annual vol. 4, #1 (LGY #43) Is Venom scary? I don’t think so, but the black symbiote suite? Yes, it was. I...
caption:
Amazing Spider-Man Annual vol. 4, #1 (LGY #43)

Is Venom scary? I don’t think so, but the black symbiote suite? Yes, it was. I loved this issue and Saladin Ahmed has quickly become one of my favorite comic book writers. The issue written from the POV of the suit back in the 1980s before Spidey knew its true nature.  It feels like a great prologue to Web of Spider-Man #1, which from my POV is the final symbiote suit story.

I have long ago dropped Spider-Man from my pull-list, but made sure to get this issue.

summary: I think one of the reasons Spider-Man: Homecoming was so good was because they skipped the origin story and left a ton of room...
body:
I think one of the reasons Spider-Man: Homecoming was so good was because they skipped the origin story and left a ton of room for the new story instead of rehashing what we’ve seen from the previous movies.

They just said “fuck it, everyone already knows the gist of it at this point, let’s just throw this small child at the Avengers and see what happens”.
